Multi-amine assisted crystal growth of large sized α-MoO3 elongated nano-plates
Sang Hwa Moona and Sang Hyuk Im*,a
Large sized α-MoO3 elongated nano-plates were synthesized by introduction of multi-amine such as ethylene di-amine and diethylene tri-amine (DETA) in conventional hydrothermal reaction. The DETA made large hexagonal rods with h-MoO3 intermediate phase containing H2O, NH4OH, and DETA ions. During hydrothermal reaction, the hexagonal rods were transformed to elongated α-MoO3 nano-plates by re-dissolution of h-MoO3 and re-growth to α-MoO3 because the DETA retards the preferred growth reaction of MoO6 octahedra to [001] direction and helps the MoO6 octahedra to grow [100] direction. In addition, the DETA promotes α-MoO3 nano-belts to be assembled into elongated nano-plates by oriented attachment because multiammonium groups in DETA back bone can adhere α-MoO3 nanobelts due to attractive coulomb interaction.
Metal oxides with controlled shape, structure, composition, and morphology have been of great interest because their optical, physical, and catalytic properties are greatly dependent on such control parameters. Most of all, the molybdenum oxides, which have oxidation states from +2 to +6, have paid attention because of their potential in applications such as a field-emitter,1-3 a semiconductor,4-7 an electrochromic material,8,9 a fuel reforming catalyst,10, 11 anode material for lithium ion batteries,12-14 and hole transporting material for photovoltaic devices.15, 16
Especially, the molybdenum trioxide with orthorhombic phase (αMoO3) has two-dimensional layered natural van der Waals crystal structure and high refractive index of 2.11.17 The layered structure is consisted of MoO6 octahedra double layer which are bonded by corner and edge sharing with covalent bonding in [100] and [001] direction and van der Waals force in [010] direction.18 So far, intensive studies have been done to control the morphology and structure of α-MoO3. Accordingly, shape and morphology controlled α-MoO3 crystals such as nano-tubes,19,20 nano-belts,4-7, 21-29 microcages,30-32 nano-flowers,33, 34 nano-sheets,35 nano-flakes,36 and nano-plates,37 have developed. However, the large sized nano-
belts, nano-sheets, and nano-flakes were prepared by high temperature calcination or evaporation.
For example, Niederberger et al. reported that morphology of αMoO3 can be controlled by using primary amine as crystal growth template, but the morphology of produced α-MoO3 nano-belts was not significantly controllable.38 Jing et al. reported direct thermal intercalation of alkyl amines into the layered MoO3 with irregular thick microplate-like morphology.39 Li et al. reported that α-MoO3 nano-belts, urchin-shaped, micro-ellipsoids, and nanolaminas can be synthesized by adjusting a concentration of cethyltrimethyl ammonium bromide surfactant.40 Except for solution chemistry, the plate-like α-MoO3 crystals can be synthesized by calcination method, however, the α-MoO3 crystals synthesized by calcination have non-uniform thick plate-like morphology or small plate-like morphology.41, 42
However, so far, there has been no reports on the synthesis of such large sized nano-belts, nano-sheets, and nano-plates through solution chemistry because the α-MoO3 prefers to grow anisotropic nanowires or nano-belts in solution chemistry due to the preferred growth to [001] direction. Therefore, it is still challenging to synthesize the large sized α-MoO3 nano-plates by solution chemistry. Here, we demonstrated that such large sized twodimensional α-MoO3 crystals can be synthesized by the solution chemistry for the first time by introducing organic amines such as mono-amines, di-amins, and tri-amines. We systematically studied the effect of mono-, di-, and tri-amines on the morphology of αMoO3 crystals in the hydrothermal solution chemistry and found that the multi-amine produced the large sized α-MoO3 elongated nano-plates by promoting oriented attachment between α-MoO3 nano-belts because it acts as a coupler combining α-MoO3 nanobelts.
<Figure 1>
For a typical synthesis of α-MoO3 nano-belts, 0.1g of ammonium heptamolybdate tetrahydrate (AHM) was dissolved in 10 ml of deionized water in a vial at room temperature by magnetically stirring for 10 min. 0.25 ml of HNO3 was then added in the solution. The mixed solution was then transferred into a Teflon-lined
autoclave. The autoclave was then heated to 270 ℃ for 30 min and

To check the effect of amines on the morphology of produced α-MoO3 particles, we added 0.46 mmol of amines in the AHM/HNO3/deionized water reaction bath and conducted hydrothermal reaction in the same manner. The scanning electron microscopy (SEM) images of produced α-MoO3 particles with respect to the introduced amine base catalysts were shown in Figure 1. The control sample prepared without amine in Figure 1(a) had thin nanobelt in shape, which is consistent with previously reported literatures.4-7, 22 To check the effect of mono-amines on the morphology of α-MoO3 particles, we introduced ammonium hydroxide, butyl amine, and hexyl amine as shown in Figure 1(b)-(d), respectively. Irrespective of variation of alkyl chain length in the mono-amine, the morphology of produced α-MoO3 does not changed significantly. In contrast, when the multiamines were introduced in the hydrothermal reaction, the morphologies of produced α-MoO3 were significantly changed as shown in Figure 1(e) and (f). The ethylene diamine produced αMoO3 nano-belts with larger width, which seem to be formed by attachment of several thin α-MoO3 nano-belts as shown in Figure 1(e). The diethylene tri-amine (DETA) produced elongated plate-like α-MoO3 nano-belts as shown in Figure 1(f) due to attachment of more number of α-MoO3 nano-belts.
<Figure 2>
To check if the elongated plate-like α-MoO3 nanobelt is formed to single crystal by oriented attachment, we analyzed transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images as shown in Figure 2. The upper left inset is a schematic crystal structure of α-MoO3, which has lattice distance of a = 3.966 Å, c = 3.693 Å, and b = 13.853 Å.43 The lower inset is low magnified TEM image showing a single elongated plate-like α-MoO3 nanobelt. The square part was measured for TEM analysis. The upper right inset is a selective area electron diffraction (SAED) pattern of α-MoO3 indicating that the lattice distance of a = 0.4 nm and c = 0.37 nm. This indicates that the α-MoO3 nanobelt prefers to grow to [001] direction and the elongated plate-like αMoO3 nanobelt is formed by further growth to [100] direction. To check if the elongated plate-like α-MoO3 nanobelt is formed by oriented attachment, we checked the TEM images of (a)-(e) points. All TEM images do not exhibit any lattice mismatches at the regions of which two α-MoO3 nano-belts are attached. Therefore, we can think that the elongated plate-like α-MoO3 nanobelt is a single crystal formed by oriented attachment of α-MoO3 nano-belts.
To elucidate how the elongated plate-like α-MoO3 nano-belts can be formed by introduction of multi-amines, we checked what was happened with reaction time in the control sample and the DETA sample as shown in Figure S1 and Figure 3. The X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns (Figure S1(a)) and SEM images (Figure S1(b)-(g)) of the control sample were measured with the reaction time. Hereafter, the reaction time is defined to the elapsed time after the reactor temperature reached to 270oC. The XRD patterns indicate that the hexagonal phase MoO3 (h-MoO3) is formed in early reaction stage and is maintained to 10-15 min. At 15 min, the h-
MoO3 phase and α-MoO3 phase were mixed and after then α-MoO3 phase is only appeared. The only appearance of (010) planes in the XRD patterns of α-MoO3 phase confirm that the produced α-MoO3 nano-belts have layered structure with preferred orientation. The SEM image in Figure S1(b) indicates that the thick hexagonal rods are formed in early reaction stage due to the formation of h-MoO3. As the reaction proceeds, apparently the hexagonal rods are sharpened by dissolution of h-MoO3 under the hydrothermal reaction condition as shown in Figure S1(c) and transformation to α-MoO3. Therefore, at 15 min reaction time period, the sharped hexagonal rods and thin nano-belts are mixed as shown in Figure S1(d) due to the co-existence of h-MoO3 and α-MoO3. After then, only relatively short nano-belts are formed and are further grown to long nano-belts as shown in Figure S1(e)-(g).
<Figure 3>
The X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns (Figure 3(a)) and SEM images (Figure 3(b)-(g)) of the DETA sample were also measured with the reaction time. Similar to the control sample, the XRD patterns indicate that the h-MoO3 phase is formed in early reaction stage and α-MoO3 phase only remained in late reaction stage. However, the transformation reaction rate from h-MoO3 phase to α-MoO3 phase slowed down significantly. The h-MoO3 phase remained in the reaction bath up to 70 min in the DETA sample, whereas the hMoO3 phase disappeared within 20 min in the control sample. The SEM image indicates that the hexagonal rods were formed in 10 min of reaction time as shown in Figure 3(b). As reaction proceeded, the hexagonal rods had cracks and porosities on their surface by dissolution of h-MoO3 intermediate rods as shown in Figure 3(c) and they were almost disappeared by forming elongated plates as shown in Figure 3(d) and (e). After then, the elongated plates were further grown to the elongated plate-like pure α-MoO3 nano-belts as shown in Figure 3(f) and (g).
In the presence of excess H+, the AHM can form MoO3 via h-MoO3 intermediate phase. The involved chemical reaction is as follow: 44
(NH4)6Mo7O24∙4H2O + 6HNO3
→ 6NH4+ + Mo7O246- + 4H2O + 6H+ + 6NO3- (1) Mo7O246- + 3H+ → (H–O)3Mo7O213- (2) (H–O)3Mo7O213- + 3H+ → (H–O)6Mo7O18 → 7MoO3 + 3H2O (3)
This implies that the higher concentration of H+ (acidity) promotes the forward reaction to form MoO3. Accordingly, it can be naturally understood why the forward reaction rate slowed down by addition of DETA, which generated OH- ions to form H2O by reaction with H+ ions. In addition, in order to ensure that the oxygen ions prolapse from AHM to form H2O molecules, excessive acid concentration is necessary.45 Therefore, the transformation reaction rate from hMoO3 intermediate phase to α-MoO3 phase is also retarded by addition of DETA. If the concentration of the DETA is further increased to 1mmol, the larger elongated α-MoO3 nano-plates are not formed as shown in Figure S2. Rather, aggregated nano-belts

<Figure 4>
The h-MoO3 intermediate phase is formed in the presence of H+ ions and NH3+ ions for the control sample and H+, NH3+, and DETA ions (H3+N(CH2)2NH2+(CH2)2NH3+) so it is expected that the composition of the h-MoO3 intermediate phase formed in the control sample is different from that formed in the DETA sample even though both h-MoO3 intermediate phase exhibited similar hexagonal rod in shape. Therefore, we checked Fourier transforminfrared (FT-IR) spectra of h-MoO3 intermediate phase and α-MoO3 phase in control and DETA sample as shown in Figure 4(a) and (b).
In FT-IR spectra, 809 and 817 cm-1 peaks of α-MoO3 are Mo-O stretching vibration mode; 865 and 868 cm-1 peaks of h-MoO3 and 858 cm-1 peak of α-MoO3 are Mo-O-Mo stretching vibration mode; 970, 972, and 1060 cm-1 peaks of h-MoO3 and 962, 979, 1066, and 1074 cm-1 peaks of α-MoO3 are Mo=O symmetric stretching vibration mode; 1400 and 1435 cm-1 peaks of h-MoO3 are N-H bending vibration by DETA; 3226 and 3172 cm-1 peaks of h-MoO3 are N-H stretching vibration by DETA; 3676 cm-1 peak of h-MoO3 and 3665 and 3676 cm-1 peaks of α-MoO3 are O-H stretching vibration by H2O; and 1602, 1610, 2905, and 2982 cm-1 peaks of hMoO3 and 2901, 2895, 2976, and 2984 cm-1 peaks of α-MoO3 are OH bending vibration by H2O.
Figure 4(a) indicates that both h-MoO3 intermediate phases contain H2O and N-H group from NH4OH and/or DETA. The h-MoO3 intermediate phase formed by the control sample contained small quantity of H2O and NH4OH, whereas the h-MoO3 intermediate phase formed by the DETA sample exhibited abundant H2O and NH4OH/DETA ions (H3+N(CH2)2NH2+(CH2)2NH3+) because it has FT-IR absorption peak at 1255 cm-1 (C-N peak) and 1313 cm-1 (C-H peak) by inclusion of DETA within h-MoO3 structure. Hence, it is expected that the h-MoO3 intermediate phase formed by the DETA sample will be more porous than that formed by the control sample due to the more inclusion of H2O and NH4OH/DETA ions within structure. However, both α-MoO3 nano-belts and elongated nano-plates did not have significant H2O and NH4OH/DETA ions within structure as shown in Figure 4(b).
When we checked the pH variations of the control sample and the DETA sample with the reaction time, the pH of the control sample was maintained below 0.8 without significant change with reaction time due to excess H+. In contrast, the pH of the DETA sample was increased to over 1.0 as soon as the h-MoO3 intermediate phase is transformed to the α-MoO3 phase. This clearly confirms that the DETA ions/NH4OH is included within the hMoO3 intermediate phase in early reaction stage and is released to the reaction solution by the formation of α-MoO3 phase. Therefore, the h-MoO3 intermediate phase might be in the form of (H2O)x7MoO3(O(NH4)2)y for control sample and in the form of (H2O)x7MoO3(O(DETA ion)2)y(O(NH4)2)z for DETA sample.46
Thermal gravimetric analysis (TGA) spectra of h-MoO3 intermediate phase in control and DETA sample was conducted to check how much the H2O and NH4OH/DETA ions are included within the h-MoO3 intermediate phase as shown in Figure 4(c). Below 200oC, the H2O molecules adsorbed on the surface of h-MoO3 intermediate phase might be eliminated and ~3 % of NH4OH/H2O in internal structure was gradually eliminated over 200 oC from the hMoO3 intermediate phase formed by control sample, which is consistent with the reported h-MoO3 intermediate phase (((NH4)2O)0.0866MoO3(0.231H2O)).47 The h-MoO3 intermediate phase formed by DETA sample exhibited similar H2O weight loss below 200 oC and ~3 % of weight loss at 200-300 oC, however, it had ~10.6 % of additional weight loss at 300-470 oC because the additional H2O/NH4OH/DETA ions included within h-MoO3 structure are further eliminated.
The X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) spectra of Mo 3d and O 1s element of h-MoO3 intermediate phase and α-MoO3 phase in control and DETA sample were shown in Figure 4(d) and (e). The Mo peaks and O 1s peaks were almost constant irrespective of phase and crystal structure. The deconvoluted Mo 3d peaks were consisted of Mo6+ 3d3/2 and Mo6+ 3d5/2 peaks and the deconvoluted O 1s peaks were consisted of metal oxide peak and metal hydroxide peak. So the MoO3 particles have OH groups, which is consistent with the FT-IR results. The mole ratio of Mo:O of h-MoO3 and αMoO3 in control sample was 1:2.83 and 1:2.7 and that in DETA sample was 1:3.27 and 1:2.76.
<Figure 5>
Based on the above experimental results, we draw a schematic illustration of proposed reaction mechanism for the formation of the elongated α-MoO3 nano-plates by introduction of DETA multiamine coupler in Figure 5. For the synthesis of α-MoO3, here we used AHM as molybdenum precursor, HNO3 as excess H+ donor, and DETA as multi-amine coupler. To check what is happening in early reaction stage, we measured SEM image of the sample taken out when the temperature of autoclave reached to 180 oC in the middle of elevating the reaction temperature to 270oC. Figure S3 is the SEM image indicating the formation of amorphouse-like nanorods. The amorphous-like nanorods were named to nuclei in the Figure 5. In early hydrothermal reaction stage at 270oC, the nuclei in control sample are assembled into hexagonal rods with h-MoO3 intermediate phase, which contains H2O and NH4OH for control sample and H2O, NH4OH, and DETA ions for DETA sample. During the hydrothermal reaction, the hexagonal rods are gradually disappeared through phase transformation into α-MoO3 nano-belts while releasing H2O or NH4OH or DETA ions. In the control sample, the [001] directional growth of MoO6 octahedra is preferred due to more acidic condition than the DETA sample and consequently αMoO3 nano-belts are formed. On the other hand, in the DETA sample, the growth rate slows down due to less acidic condition and the DETA multi-ions help the α-MoO3 nano-belts to be coupled

To compare current-voltage (I-V) characteristics of α-MoO3 nanobelts and α-MoO3 elongated nano-plates, we dropped 0.2 ml of αMoO3 nano-belts/ethanol (5 mg/10 ml) and α-MoO3 elongated nano-plates/ethanol (5 mg/10 ml) solution on the two Au electrodes with 45 μm gap, respectively, and dried them at 40 oC on hot-plate for 20 min. The SEM images of prepared samples were shown in Figure 6 (a, b), which indicate that similar amount of αMoO3 nano-belts and α-MoO3 elongated nano-plates are formed on the Au electrodes. Their I-V characteristics of α-MoO3 nano-belts and α-MoO3 elongated nano-plates sample in Figure 6 (c, d) indicate that the α-MoO3 elongated nano-plates can flow ~20 fold more current than the α-MoO3 nano-belts under the same applied bias voltage. This might be associated with the fact that the α-MoO3 elongated nano-plates are composed of the single crystals, whereas the α-MoO3 nano-belts are composed of bundle of α-MoO3 nanowires. In addition, we checked I-V curves of above two samples before and after ammonia adsorption as shown in Figure S4. Because the ammonia can be adsorbed by the layered van der Waals MoO3 crystals, we conceived that the current of α-MoO3 nano-belts and α-MoO3 elongated nano-plates are greatly reduced. For this, we put the sample in a 140 ml glass container and drop 0.05 ml of ammonium hydroxide solution (28-30 %, NH3 basis) in the glass container as shown in Figure S4(a). Then the glass container were sealed by a cover lock and stored it on hot-plate at 50 oC for 1 h to fully evaporate the ammonium hydroxide in the glass container. Figure S4(b, c) are I-V curves of α-MoO3 nano-belts and α-MoO3 elongated nano-plates sample before and after ammonia adsorption. As expected both samples exhibited greatly reduced current by adsorption of ammonia. The current of α-MoO3 elongated nano-plates sample was reduced by four order of magnitude by ammonia adsorption, whereas the α-MoO3 nanobelts sample exhibited three order of magnitude reduction of current. Therefore, the α-MoO3 elongated nano-plates sample is more sensitive to ammonia adsorption than the α-MoO3 nano-belts sample.
<Figure 6>

sections.heading: Conclusions
sections.text:
We successfully synthesized large sized α-MoO3 elongated nanoplates by introduction of multi-amine in hydrothermal synthesis for the first time. The control hydrothermal synthesis produced αMoO3 nano-belts through hexagonal rods with h-MoO3 intermediate phase, of which H2O and NH4OH are included within the structure under the excess H+ condition because the H+ ions enable the oxygen ions to prolapse from AHM to form H2O molecules and promote forward growth reaction of MoO6 octahedra to [001] direction. On the other hand, the DETA sample
makes relatively thicker hexagonal rods containing H2O, NH4OH, and DETA ions within their structure and retarded the forward growth reaction rate and thereby retarded preferred growth to [001] direction. In addition, the DETA ions help the thin α-MoO3 nano-belts to be assembled to elongated nano-plates by orientated attachment, whereas the mono-amines cannot do that. In addition, the elongated α-MoO3 nano-plates exhibited better conductivity than the α-MoO3 nano-belts. Therefore, the elongated α-MoO3 nano-plates detect the ammonia gas more effectively than the αMoO3 nano-belts. We believe that the proposed synthetic method for large sized α-MoO3 nano-plates will be helpful to extend applications of α-MoO3 nanomaterials.
